ja55:0.4.eng: Prince Five-Weapons: a past life story

ja55:1.1.eng: He whose heart is not stuck,
ja55:1.1.comm: A prince is named “Five-Weapons” after a prophecy when he was born. The prophecy was fulfilled when, on returning from his studies in Takkasilā in Gandhāra, he encountered a ferocious native spirit (yakkha) in a forest and fought it with five weapons. Each attack only stuck him tighter to the monster’s shaggy coat. The monster, recognizing his courage, let him go. | The five weapons are the arrow (sara), sword (khagga), javelin (kaṇaya), hammer (muggara), and lance (kunta). But his real weapon is the vajira (“diamond” or “thunderbolt”), which is the weapon of knowledge.

ja55:1.2.comm: The warrior gets “stuck” or “bound” (allīna) to his adversary, in what can be read as a metaphor for violence: one who lives by the sword is “bound” to the kamma of killing, becoming the same as those who they fight. The otherwise unrelated verse is linked to the story through the contrasting image of the mind that is “not bound” (alīna), a word that can also mean “intrepid, unwearying, brave”. In this verse and the next, the double meanings are intended by the poet, so I use the different meanings in each line.

ja55:1.4.eng: for the sake of sanctuary from the yoke.

ja56:0.4.eng: The Mass of Gold: a past life story

ja56:1.1.comm: A man discovers a large lump of gold, but must break it into four to make it useful. | The verse is almost identical with the previous, only differing in the key term.

ja56:1.2.comm: As with the previous verse, the key term pahaṭṭha rests on both the story and a dual meaning. Pahaṭṭha normally has the sense “cheerful” (√haṁs), but the commentary connects it rather with gold that has been forged (√ghaṁs) until it is luminous and radiant.

ja56:1.4.eng: for the sake of sanctuary from the yoke.

ja57:0.4.eng: The Lord of Langurs: a past life story

ja57:1.1.comm: A crocodile’s wife, being pregnant, conceives an irresistible craving (dohaḷa) to eat the heart of the monkey king. Her husband tries to satisfy her by pretending to be a rock in the river, but the monkey sees through his ruse. This is one of a cycle of dohaḷa stories in the Jātakas, which deal with the ascension of consciousness. Here the ascension fails due to the crocodile’s greed and foolishness, so it cannot consume the monkey’s heart, i.e. intelligence.

ja57:1.2.comm: In legend, the vānara is a race of aggressive human-like monkeys with long tails and hairy skin like blankets. Their leaders such as Sugrīva or Hanuman are titled “lord of langurs”. Such leaders are often found in artwork depicted as langurs, with their prominent sideburns lending them a decidedly human appearance.

ja57:1.4.comm: This last line plays on a double meaning. The commentary explains diṭṭha as “foe” (Sanskrit dviṣṭa) and the phrase as “defeats the foe”. But the crocodile shuts his eyes and opens his mouth to catch the langur, pointing to the more common meaning of diṭṭha as “seen” (Sanskrit dṛṣṭa), and yielding the sense, “transcends the seen”. The clever monkey defeats his enemy because he sees beyond mere appearances, while the crocodile is blinded by his greed.

ja58:0.4.eng: Three Qualities: a past life story

ja58:1.3.comm: Dakkhiyaṁ is an abstract neuter noun from dakkha having the sense “adroitness”. It is formed by analogy with sūriyaṁ, which here means “heroism”; compare vīriya in the same sense.

ja59:0.4.eng: The Drummer: a past life story

ja59:1.1.comm: A drummer with his boy earned money playing drums at a festival. On the return journey, however, the boy’s incessant beating attracted the attention of bandits. | The story and title speak of a “drum” (bheri), while the verse uses dhamati, which normally means “blows”. The repeated idiom recalls the onomatopoetic Sanskrit dhamadhamā, which in Marathi, Hindi, Kannada, and Nepali has the sense of a repeated drumbeat. On the other hand, the next verse is almost identical and concerns the blower of a conch or horn. Rather than rendering the two verses to match the commentary, I assume they originally had the same sense.

ja59:1.3.eng: By blowing a hundred was gained,
ja59:1.3.comm: Sataṁ is explained as “a hundred dollars”. But there is a play on words here, for sataṁ can also mean “the good, the true”.

ja6:0.4.eng: Godly Qualities: a past life story

ja6:1.1.comm: The story tells of how two brothers are asked by a water-spirit what are “godly qualities”. Their replies—“the sun and moon” and the “four directions”—win them only imprisonment. The third brother replies correctly.

ja6:1.3.eng: the good and true persons in the world

ja6:1.4.eng: are said to have godly qualities.
ja6:1.4.comm: Devadhamma (“godly qualities”) appears at Ja 458:7.3 where it means “god’s character”.

ja60:0.4.eng: The Horn-Blower: a past life story

ja60:1.1.comm: The story is similar to the previous, except here the instrument is a conch or horn, and the father is the overplayer, not the son.

ja60:1.2.comm: Mil 3.1.4:6.8 discusses what happens when a horn player breathes out too much.

ja60:1.4.eng: but your blowing dad blew it.
ja60:1.4.comm: Dhamaṁ is nominative singular. We can capture the pun between dhama (“blowing”) and vidhamī (“squandered it”, “blew it”).

ja61:0.4.eng: The Spell of the Unpleasant: a past life story

ja61:1.1.eng: The women in the world called unclaimed—
ja61:1.1.comm: A young student is told by his mother that his education is incomplete until he learns the mysterious “spell of the unpleasant”. His teacher knows that there is no such spell, but realizes that the mother wants her son to learn of the wickedness of women. | Read asā from a + sva, “without an owner”, and hence “unclaimed” or “without a husband”. The commentary explains, rather, as asatiyo (“false”) and also asāta (“displeasing”). Perhaps the curious “spell of the unpleasant” was retroactively invented to explain this word.

ja61:1.3.eng: They are rude and full of desires,

ja61:1.5.eng: Leaving them behind, I shall go forth

ja62:0.4.eng: Since Infancy: a past life story

ja62:1.1.comm: An innocent baby girl was sold into slavery and kept locked up under guard her entire life by a brahmin who married her. This was to feed his gambling addiction by refuting his adversary’s lucky charm, which was an asseveration of truth that all women were faithless. When the brahmin started winning at dice, his adversary employed a knave to restore his fortunes. Cruelly deceiving her waiting-woman, the knave managed to sneak in and seduce the wife. To help the knave make his escape, the young wife persuaded her husband to play the harp while she danced, asking him to cover his eyes for modesty’s sake. On discovering the ruse, the brahmin beat his wife and chased her away. Somehow, the moral of the story is that women can’t be trusted!

ja62:1.2.comm: The brahmin of this story is depicted in a Bharhut sculpture, Plate 26, 8.

ja62:1.3.eng: had raised his wife since infancy—

ja62:1.4.eng: who would ever trust such women?

ja63:0.4.eng: The Philosopher: a past life story

ja63:1.1.comm: These first lines were uttered as an imprecation, which according to the commentary was against women. Note, however, that the grammatical gender is ambiguous except for akataññū, which is masculine plural. Either a non-standard form is used, or the verse was not originally about women. | Takka normally means “logic”, and the alternate meaning “buttermilk”, while possible, is unnecessary. The story says that an ascetic, unable to stop himself from taking sexual advantage of a vulnerable woman in his care, blamed her when he was reduced to employment as adviser to villagers.

ja63:1.4.eng: you will not be bereft of happiness.
ja63:1.4.comm: The reading of vihāhasi is uncertain. I follow the commentary.

ja64:0.4.eng: Hard to Understand: a past life story

ja64:1.1.comm: When a wife has been good, she expects her husband to be nice to her; but when she has been bad, she is nice to him. The complexity of these behaviors is evidently too much for her husband, who seeks counsel for his confusion. Rather than make an effort to understand his wife, he is advised to simply ignore her feelings.

ja64:1.3.eng: The mood of women is hard to understand,
ja64:1.3.comm: Thīnaṁ is genitive plural, glossed itthīnaṁ. | The Dhamma is also “hard to understand” (Snp 3.12:59.1).

ja64:1.4.eng: like the track of fish in water.

ja65:1.1.comm: The story tells us that women are available to all, so the wise do not get upset when they are unfaithful. | Contrary to the story, studies consistently indicate that men cheat more than women.

ja65:1.3.eng: are those called women in the world.

ja65:1.4.eng: Sages do not get angry with them.
ja65:1.4.comm: Nāsaṁ is na + āsaṁ, genitive plural feminine pronoun.

ja66:0.4.eng: Queen Sweetheart: a past life story

ja66:1.1.eng: One wish I had in the past,
ja66:1.1.comm: An ascetic desires the queen, but when he gains her he finds that his list of desires does not shrink but grows.

ja66:1.3.eng: But when I won the moon-eyed lady,
ja66:1.3.comm: Aḷārakkhī is unique. More commonly we find aḷārapamha, where, as here aḷāra is glossed as visāla, “wide”. Compare Sanskrit arāḍa, glossed with ucchritaśṛṅga, “high-horned”. I think it describes wide-open, expressive eyes (akkhī) with eyebrows (pamha) that are high and curved like horns.

ja66:1.4.comm: Vijāyatha is reflexive third singular aorist, glossed with janesi.

ja67:0.4.eng: In My Lap: a past life story

ja67:1.1.eng: A son in my lap, your highness,
ja67:1.1.comm: A woman’s son, husband, and brother are held by the king, who forces her to choose just one. She chooses her brother, as the others may be readily replaced. The king, impressed with her reasoning, releases all three. | Ucchaṅge (“lap”) here is a sexual innuendo; the commentary likens it to a “bag” in which vegetables are kept.

ja67:1.2.eng: or a husband while walking the street—
ja67:1.2.comm: She can pick up a husband on the street as easily as she can conceive a son in her “lap”.

ja67:1.3.eng: but I don’t see the place

ja67:1.4.eng: from where I can fetch a brother.

ja68:0.4.eng: At Sāketa: a past life story

ja68:1.1.comm: This only refers to events of the past, with no proper story. In the present, an old couple dotes on the Buddha as their son, and he confirms that they were his parents in many past lives. | The remaining stories of this chapter do not concern women.

ja68:1.2.eng: and the heart too is confident—

ja69:0.4.eng: Vomited Poison: a past life story

ja69:1.1.comm: A snake refuses to take back its poison even on pain of death.

ja69:1.2.eng: which I vomited for the sake of life
ja69:1.2.comm: For jīvitakāraṇā in the sense “for the sake of life”, see Ps 1.1:215.2.

ja69:1.3.comm: The verse can be read in two ways. The story assumes that the snake refuses to take back the poison. But there is no negative particle qualifying the verb, so it must be read as a rhetorical question: “I shall take back what I have vomited?” In this reading, they refuse to take it back even “for the sake of life” because they are threatened with death if they refuse. Alternatively, however, the speaker is saying that they have vomited the poison for the sake of life—i.e. that they took a purgative—but nonetheless they shall eat their poisoned vomit even though it means their death. In this reading, the speaker is likely a person rather than a snake, and the “vomit” actual vomit, not emitted poison. The reason why they resort to such drastic measures is not clear, and I fear we have lost the original story that would have made the context meaningful. Nonetheless, I think this interpretation reflects the Pali more directly.

ja69:1.4.eng: Death is better for me than life!

ja7:0.4.eng: The Wood Gatherer: a past life story

ja7:1.1.eng: I am your son, great king!
ja7:1.1.comm: The story tells of a king who visited a park. Spying a simple country girl gathering wood, he became enamoured and they had sex. Knowing that she had conceived, she told the king, who gave her a signet ring. Later, she presented herself with the child at court, but the king denied them, even when the ring was shown. Not until the child was thrown in the air did the king relent.

ja7:1.2.eng: Provide for me, ruler of the people.

ja7:1.4.eng: what then of his own offspring?

ja70:0.4.eng: The Spade: a past life story

ja70:1.1.eng: That victory is not a good victory
ja70:1.1.comm: A gardener goes forth as an ascetic, but can’t stop thinking about their favorite spade.

ja70:1.3.eng: That victory is a good victory

ja71:0.4.eng: The Warding Tree: a past life story

ja71:1.1.comm: A lazy pupil takes a nap while others are gathering firewood. At the last moment, he carelessly snaps a green branch off the Warding Tree, hurting his eye in the process; and when it came time for breakfast, the fire would not light.

ja71:1.2.eng: tasks they should have done before,

ja71:1.3.eng: like the one who broke a branch off the Warding Tree,
ja71:1.3.comm: Varaṇa (or varuṇa, Crateva religiosa) is from the root var “to ward”. It is associated with Vedic rites of the dead and with “warding off” demons, foes, and all manner of ills (Atharva Veda 10.3). Vedic ritualists were very particular about what wood was to be used for what purpose (eg. Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 13.8.4.1), and varaṇa wood, due to its association with the rites of death, was not to be used to make offerings in the life-giving Homa fire ritual (Maitrāyaṇī Saṁhitā 1.6.7). The association of the varaṇa with death is maintained in the commentarial story behind Ja 38, where the crane kills fish on a branch of this tree. This verse, I suggest, was originally a warning against using the wrong wood for the ritual.

ja72:0.4.eng: The Virtuous Elephant: a past life story

ja72:1.1.comm: A magnificent white elephant rescues a lost man and returns him home on his back. But, falling prey to greed, the man asks for ivory from the elephant’s tusks. The noble creature freely offered his tusks to the ungrateful wretch.

ja72:1.3.eng: even if given the whole earth,

ja73:0.4.eng: The Truth, It Seems: a past life story

ja73:1.1.eng: The truth, it seems, was spoken
ja73:1.1.comm: An ascetic saved a prince, a parrot, a rat, and a snake from a flood. Since the animals were in greater need, he fed them first. While the animals were all grateful, the proud prince conceived a hatred, which he nursed until he ascended the throne and sought revenge for the imagined slight.

ja73:1.3.comm: I translate literally, but the verse seems to need the verb “rescue” supplied by the commentary (uttāretvā).

ja74:0.4.eng: The Law of Trees: a past life story

ja74:1.1.eng: It is well for the many relatives,
ja74:1.1.comm: While the verse speaks only of trees, the story says that the deities who live in trees are advised to dwell only in those clustered together in the forest. Some deities, however, greedy for human offerings, set up home in trees worshipped as shrines by villages.

ja74:1.2.eng: the trees born in the forest.

ja74:1.3.eng: The wind sweeps off one standing alone,

ja74:1.4.eng: even the enormous lord of the forest.

ja75:0.4.eng: The Fish: a past life story

ja75:1.1.comm: Due to drought, a pond dried out and the crows feasted on the fish. One of the fish prayed for salvation to the god of rain, Pajjuna, who appears also in DN 20:17.7. The previous verse featured Vāta, the wind, following which comes Pajjuna, the thunderstorm. Thus the two go together, as they do often in the Vedas. | The story and this verse appears in Cp 30, where it illustrates the perfection of truth.

ja75:1.2.eng: Wipe out the trove of the crow!
ja75:1.2.comm: The commentary says the sense is that the stranded fish are the “trove” (nidhi) of the feasting crow, which is “wiped out” by being covered with water.

ja75:1.3.comm: Pajjuna is fructifying and blessed, but also fearful and destructive (Rig Veda 5.83).

ja75:1.4.comm: Cp 30:7.6 has macche (“the fish”) instead of mañca (“me”). If mañca is accepted, there is no mention of fish in the verse. The original verse may have focused more specifically on the “trove of the crow”, i.e. the deathly drought, from which the waters offer relief. | In Vedic tradition, the waters are invoked to save one from the sin wiped by the crow’s mouth, the kiss of the dread goddess of black death, Nirṛti (Atharva Veda 7.64). The wish to harm the crow is distinctly un-Buddhist and more characteristic of the Atharva. Otherwise, though, the two passages are not similar, except they both end with the same verb.

ja76:1.1.eng: I am unsuspecting in the village;
ja76:1.1.comm: An ascetic is unafraid even in the presence of bandits, for he has nothing to lose.

ja76:1.2.eng: in the wilderness there’s no peril for me:

ja76:1.3.eng: I ride upon the straight path
ja76:1.3.comm: For this idiom, see MN 12:39.7. Samārūḷha is literally “mounted”; the expression refers to travelling along on a horse, etc.

ja77:0.4.eng: Sixteen Great Dreams: a past life story

ja77:1.1.comm: King Pasenadi is perturbed by sixteen dreams, but the Buddha assures him that these do not affect him, but are portents of times to come. Each dream depicts an inversion or perversion of the just order of things. | Four snorting black bulls depart without fighting. | Sapling trees flower. | Cows suckle at newborn calves. | Oxen are unyoked and calves given the reins.

ja77:1.2.comm: A horse eats from two mouths. | People beg a jackal to defecate in a fine goblet. | A she-jackal eats a rope as it is being spun. | People pour water into a full pitcher.

ja77:1.3.comm: A lotus-pond is muddy in the middle and clear on the edges. | Rice will not cook. | People barter sour milk for sandalwood.

ja77:2.2.comm: Text reads supaṇṇa (“phoenix”), but commentary reads suvaṇṇa (“golden”), explaining as “golden royal geese” (suvaṇṇarājahaṁsa).

ja77:2.3.eng: the wolf trembles for fear of the sheep.”
ja77:2.3.comm: The verse has seven lines, with each pair of lines having a different metre: opacchandasaka, vetālīya, and tuṭṭhubha for the last three.

ja77:2.4.eng: No perversion of reality is happening here for me.
ja77:2.4.comm: This sentence is a prose addendum. It seems to be an affirmation for someone suffering bad dreams: they remind themselves that the perverse, upside-down things they saw in the dream are not real.
